title: How to Make Spinach Pie

steps.headline: Drain the spinach.
steps.description: Transfer the spinach to a colander to allow excess water to drain out. Press the spinach into the colander with your hand to remove even more water. Finally, transfer the spinach to the center of a clean tea towel. Roll the spinach in the towel and wring it out to remove the last bit of water. Draining the spinach will prevent the filo dough from becoming soggy.

steps.headline: Cook the onions.
steps.description: Pour the 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of oil into a large saucepan. Heat the pan over medium heat. When the surface of the oil is shimmering, add the onion. Cook the onion for about 5 minutes, until it’s softened and starting to become translucent. Good oils for cooking the onion include olive, canola, coconut, or vegetable.

steps.headline: Add the garlic and spinach.
steps.description: Stir in the garlic and cook it with the onion for about 15 seconds, until the mixture is fragrant. Then add the spinach and cook the vegetables for another 5 minutes. To use fresh spinach instead of frozen, add the spinach in batches, and cook the mixture until the spinach is dark green and wilted.

steps.headline: Add the parsley, dill, and cheese.
steps.description: Transfer the hot spinach mixture to a large mixing bowl. Add the herbs and cheese and stir well to incorporate all the ingredients. Set the mixture aside to cool for about 30 minutes. This will ensure the eggs don’t cook when you add them. You can replace some of the feta with other cheeses, such as ricotta or jack cheese.

steps.headline: Add the eggs and pepper.
steps.description: Crack the eggs into a medium bowl. Whisk the eggs briefly to break up the yolks, and add them to the cooled spinach mixture. Add the pepper, to taste. Mix the filling well to incorporate all the ingredients, and distribute the eggs evenly throughout the mixture.

steps.headline: Oil a baking dish.
steps.description: Use a pastry brush to spread a thin layer of olive oil over the bottom and sides of a 9 by 13 inches (23 by 33 cm) baking dish. This will help the filo dough to cook evenly and become crispy without burning.

steps.headline: Roll out the filo dough.
steps.description: Lay a large piece of parchment paper on a flat surface, like a counter. Unroll the thawed filo dough and place it on the parchment. Cover the filo with a slightly damp tea towel or sheets of paper towel. Never leave the filo uncovered, or it will dry out very quickly.

steps.headline: Lay down a layer of filo.
steps.description: Remove a sheet of filo from the pile and cover the rest with the towel. Place the sheet into the baking dish, slightly off center so the edges overhang the sides of the baking dish. Repeat 5 times, slightly overlapping the filo so the entire bottom and sides of the dish are covered with an even layer of dough.

steps.headline: Brush the filo with oil.
steps.description: Use the pastry brush to apply a thin and even layer of oil to the filo. Make sure you cover the entire surface of the dough; otherwise, it may dry out during the baking process.

steps.headline: Lay down a second layer.
steps.description: Repeat the same process, laying down 6 separate sheets of filo to cover the baking dish with another even layer of dough. When you’ve finished, use the pastry brush to brush the dough with a layer of oil.

steps.headline: Fill the dough.
steps.description: Pour the filling mixture into the center of the filo-covered baking dish. Use a spoon or spatula to distribute the filling evenly throughout the baking dish.

steps.headline: Cover the filling.
steps.description: One at a time, fold the overhanging pieces of filo over the filling. When there are no more pieces hanging, cover the top with two sheets of filo. Tuck in the edges down the side of the baking dish. Use a pastry brush to coat the top sheet with a layer of oil. Repeat three more times, so the spanakopita is covered with 8 sheets of filo.

steps.headline: Bake the spanakopita.
steps.description: Transfer the spanakopita to an oven that’s been preheated to 375 °F (191 °C). Bake the pie until the top is crispy and the filo is golden brown. This will take between 35 and 45 minutes. Remove the spanakopita from the oven, cut into portions, and serve hot.

steps.headline: Activate the yeast.
steps.description: In a small bowl, combine the yeast, sugar, and ¼ cup (59 ml) of the warm water. Set the mixture aside for about 10 minutes. During this time, the yeast will begin to eat the sugar, and the mixture will become bubbly and foamy.

steps.headline: Make the dough.
steps.description: In the bowl of a stand mixer, whisk together the flour and 1 teaspoon (6 g) of the salt. Add the canola oil, yeast mixture, and ½ cup (118 ml) of warm water. Use the dough hook attachment to mix all the ingredients together to create a soft, tacky dough. Add more water if the dough is too dry. If you don’t have a stand mixer, you can mix the dough by hand or with a pastry knife.

steps.headline: Rest the dough.
steps.description: Coat the dough ball with a thin layer of oil. Transfer the dough to a large mixing bowl and cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a damp tea towel. Set the dough aside somewhere warm to rise for 90 minutes. The top of a refrigerator is an ideal spot for the dough, or an oven with the heat off and the light on.

steps.headline: Make the filling.
steps.description: In a medium mixing bowl, combine the drained spinach, onion, black pepper, cinnamon, lemon juice, and another teaspoon (6 g) of salt. Stir the mixture well to incorporate all the ingredients. You can use fresh spinach in place of the frozen, and can substitute allspice for the cinnamon if you like.

steps.headline: Roll out the dough.
steps.description: Transfer the dough to a dry, flat work surface, such as a clean counter. Use a rolling pin to roll the dough out into a large circle that’s ⁄8 inch (3.2 mm) thick.

steps.headline: Cut the dough.
steps.description: Use a round cookie cutter that’s 4 inches (10 cm) in diameter. Cut out as many circles from the dough as you can. Collect the dough scraps and form them back into a ball. Roll out the dough again and cut out as many rounds as you can.

steps.headline: Make the individual pies.
steps.description: Drop a heaping tablespoonful of filling into the center of a pastry round, and top the filling with a few pine nuts. Grab the outside of the dough in three separate places, and bring those three points together to form a triangular pocket. Pinch the top together, and then pinch together the seams to seal the pie. Repeat with the remaining pies. You can use chopped walnuts in place of the pine nuts.

steps.headline: Bake the fatayer.
steps.description: Arrange the individual pies on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Use a pastry brush to brush the top and sides of each pie with olive oil. Transfer the baking sheet to an oven that’s been preheated to 375 °F (191 °C). Bake the pies until golden brown, about 18 to 20 minutes. You may have to cook the pies in two batches.

steps.headline: Make the dough.
steps.description: In a large mixing bowl, combine the flour, butter, shortening, and ½ teaspoon (3 g) of the salt. Mix the ingredients together with a fork or pastry knife. Add the ice water in 1-tablespoon (15-ml) increments, until the mixture comes together as a soft and elastic dough. Shape the dough into a ball and cover the bowl with a damp towel. Refrigerate the dough for at least 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Form the pie shell.
steps.description: Remove the dough from the refrigerator and turn it out onto a lightly floured surface. Use a rolling pin to roll the dough into a circle that’s 11 inches (28 cm) in diameter. Use a spatula to lift the dough and transfer it to a 9 inches (23 cm) pie dish or tart pan. Gently press the dough into the bottom and sides of the dish to make a shell.

steps.headline: Bake the pie shell.
steps.description: Transfer the shell to an oven that’s been preheated to 375 °F (191 °C). Bake the shell for 20 minutes, until it’s lightly browned. Remove the shell from the oven and set it aside to cool.

steps.headline: Toast the pine nuts.
steps.description: Transfer the pine nuts to a baking sheet. Transfer the nuts to the oven and toast them for 3 to 5 minutes, until golden brown. Remove the nuts from the oven and set them aside.

steps.headline: Make the vegetable filling.
steps.description: Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the onions and sauté them for 3 minutes, until soft. Add the spinach, salt, and pepper, and cook for an additional 2 minutes, or until the liquid has evaporated. Remove the pan from the heat and set it aside to cool. It’s important to cool the vegetable mixture for at least 20 minutes so that the heat won’t cook the eggs when you add them.

steps.headline: Add the eggs and cream.
steps.description: In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the eggs and heavy cream. Add the cooled vegetable mixture and stir well to combine all the ingredients. Stir in the pine nuts and cheese and mix to incorporate. If you like heat, add a pinch of cayenne pepper to the mixture as well.

steps.headline: Bake the tart.
steps.description: Pour the filling into the cooled pie shell. Transfer the tart to the oven and bake until golden brown, about 35 to 40 minutes. Remove the tart from the oven and cool for 5 to 10 minutes before serving.
